text: I use toggl as well- but I'm also pretty bad at turning clocks on and off. But just having the toggl app as a place to double check my time every day, helps. It's apart of my daily “to-dos” and I make sure im clocked in daily to see how long projects take me.

text:
I use Clockify for client projects and one of my own websites which I'm trying to treat as if it were a client's. It helps me average out how much time I spend on different tasks, which makes it easier to time block work on my calendar.
If something has taken longer or shorter than planned, I adjust the time block on my calendar so I can always go back and have a visual of how much time I spent on things as well.

elements.text:

text:
Between Dubsado and ClickUp, I record everything so that I know how much time I am spending on client work.

For other business things...not as much haha

Edit to clarify: I track time spent working on projects that I bill hourly on Dubsado straight to the invoice. I also sometimes run the clock different from Dubsado and ClickUp because I will sometimes stop actively working on client work to research how to do something or figure out where I went wrong on something. This isn't *technically* what the client pays me for, so I don't bill those hours but track them in ClickUp for myself.

text: Thanks for asking! The biggest need I have is an editor who knows the electronic payments space specifically in the eurozone, and those topics are the main ones for which we’re writing content. I don’t have a financial/payments background (I am a dumb American in NorCal), so I need the European sensibility to help edit these topics.

text: Fellow freelancers! Who here uses Freshbooks? What do you love and/or hate about it? I currently use Quickbooks but am not totally thrilled with it.

elements.text: Fellow freelancers! Who here uses Freshbooks? What do you love and/or hate about it? I currently use Quickbooks but am not totally thrilled with it.

text:
I do! Honestly, it’s the first platform I tried (Xero seemed excessively expensive, something didn’t feel right about Quickbooks and I HATED the UX of FreeAgent).

I like that it’s very intuitive (I had no prior experience with invoicing software) and easy to use for the price. I have customised invoices to look nice (total vanity feature, but why not). I can connect my bank and expenses. Support is pretty good. I can invite my accountant to view my ‘books’.

Bills are easy to set up, and tweak in terms of deposits/dates, 50% upfront fees etc. It integrates with Stripe.

Currently I’m running 2 accounts on there due to switching from sole trader to a ltd company and it was easy to set up.

Anything you specifically want to know/want more info on?

elements.text:
I do! Honestly, it’s the first platform I tried (Xero seemed excessively expensive, something didn’t feel right about Quickbooks and I HATED the UX of FreeAgent).

I like that it’s very intuitive (I had no prior experience with invoicing software) and easy to use for the price. I have customised invoices to look nice (total vanity feature, but why not). I can connect my bank and expenses. Support is pretty good. I can invite my accountant to view my ‘books’.

Bills are easy to set up, and tweak in terms of deposits/dates, 50% upfront fees etc. It integrates with Stripe.

Currently I’m running 2 accounts on there due to switching from sole trader to a ltd company and it was easy to set up.

Anything you specifically want to know/want more info on?

text: I use it and love it. I like how the time tracking integrates with invoices (I can track hours by client and then just add them to my invoice every month); I like how time tracking by project lets me see if I’m going above or below my estimated hours/project; I like how I can download and send PDFs of invoices to clients or just dynamic links; I like how I can set up auto-reminders to clients; I like how the reporting lets me look at revenue by client over the year/months/etc. I don’t love accepting payments through Freshbooks because they charge an extra fee, but you can turn that feature off if you don’t want to use it (and almost all of my clients use <http://Bill.com|Bill.com> or Gusto or a similar payment platform anyway).

elements.text: I use it and love it. text: Thank you both!! I’m still trying to figure out how I want to do invoicing—right now it’s actually manual and I have a designed Google Sheet I use :sweat_smile:  I think I’d do something similar and not accept payments through Freshbooks though, as all of my clients either do direct deposit or a payment platform.

text: I've used FreshBooks since the very beginning... I still love it. It's really straightforward and always makes me wonder if I'm missing something when people talk about how complex invoicing and accounting can be...

text:
Have a new client who keeps trying to increase the scope of the project which isn't in our agreement. I have a process where I send an outline for approval so I can nail down the scope of the article & reduce edits. This is the first client I've had in 3 years that has used up 3 different editing cycles. 
Luckily, this is our first trial month. And I don't think they're a good fit for me. And I won't be continuing the relationship once this project is complete.

elements.text:
Have a new client who keeps trying to increase the scope of the project which isn't in our agreement. I have a process where I send an outline for approval so I can nail down the scope of the article & reduce edits. Luckily, this is our first trial month. And I don't think they're a good fit for me. And I won't be continuing the relationship once this project is complete.

text:
Also, they refused to provide me with a brand tone of voice or guideline. And their first point of call is to point out that their brand wouldn't use a particular phrase. 
And I'm here like "if you have provided me a brand tone of voice like I asked 3 times before, we wouldn't be here".
Luckily, I provide 3 rounds of edits for each article. After that, I charge $50 per editing cycle. 

*Sorry for the two reply rants*
Needed to get this off my chest with people who actually get it!

text:
Build out the things you have to have on the front end. Style guide, etc. If they don’t have them, then have an option to pay you to create it for them. If they won’t do that, then don’t work with them.

Also, to the “increase the scope”, why are you not pitching them on an increased scope for more $$?
